Eric Larson of the San Diego County Farm Bureau says farmers knew when they signed on to the discounted water program that they would be the first to ration during a drought.
But he says it's just hard to believe that time has come.
This program was developed in 1994.
And estimates were, boy, those cuts could come every eight to 10 years.
Who was to know?
And I think everyone's gotten comfortable that it hasn't happened over such a long period of time.
On one hand, you could say we've been lucky.
The farmers haven't had to take cuts.
On the other hand, now that it's here, it's a very, very difficult situation to deal with.
Water managers throughout California are dealing with unprecedented shortages.

The Colorado River is in the 8th year of a drought, the northern California snowpack is at historically low levels, and a federal judge has just mandated drastic cuts in water sent from the Sacramento Delta to Southern California in attempts to save an endangered fish.
Jeff Kightlinger, general manager of the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California says he had no choice but to cut the farmers off.
We caught up with him at a recent meeting of Western Water managers.
He says more rationing will be needed if lawmakers can't figure out a way to fix that state's water woes.
So right now, we're working very cooperatively with the state legislator and the governor to try and come up with infrastructure fixes that will address that issue.

The water cutbacks were the main topic at this month's farm bureau meeting in San Diego.

He was also an extra in this new series.
And for him, seeing his community on the big screen was exciting and a little weird.
I'll never forget the real manhunt for Richard Matt and David Sweat.
It was a stressful, exhausting time.

And I understand that people are still skeptical who work at the prison probably, who know what we're putting out there.

New York's North Country is a pretty remote place, where Clinton Correctional Facility is a big part of the economy.
